DOC.HEAD: Communist Newspaper Apologizes For Past Attacks
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After two decades of virulent attacks on dissidents and reformers, the Communist Party's daily newspaper apologized Monday to ``all those who were hurt'' on its pages. ``Over the past years our paper printed a number of stories which our editors cannot be proud of,'' Rude Pravo's new editor, Zdenek Porybny, wrote in a commentary. He admitted that ``serious political debate was abandoned in favor of personal attacks and the scandalization of people whose opinions differed from those of the Communist leadership.'' The newspaper tried to discredit Alexander Dubcek, the leader of the failed ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968, and former dissident Vaclav Havel, now a leading presidential candidate. ``Stories like `Stool Pigeon', `Who is Vaclav Havel,' `Dubcek's Journey From Tragedy to Farce' and others did not express ... the (true) attitudes of most of the paper's editors,'' according to the commentary. In July, Rude Pravo accused Dubcek of ``naive blindness,'' and of being a figure whose words were ``full of megalomania.'' One frequent tactic by the newspaper was to imply that its targets had fascist links. In one of its articles, Rude Pravo recounted that a ballroom in central Prague built by Havel's family was used by the Nazis during the occupation in World War II. ``An apology to all those who were hurt on the pages of Rude Pravo is appropriate and on the behalf of the paper's editors and myself ... I am doing just that,'' Porybny said. Porybny replaced Zdenek Horeni as editor-in-chief of the paper in a leadership reshuffle that followed a month of sweeping political change. It is just one of several changes in Czechoslovakia's state-controlled media. A new editor has taken charge of the state news agency CTK, former government spokesman Miroslav Pavel has moved to head state TV, and a new editor-in-chief also has been appointed at state radio. Czechoslovakia's opposition has forced an end to Communist domination in the government and the reforms have swept through the media, which now criticize the mistakes of the previous hard-line Communist leadership. But a statement issued Monday by Rude Pravo editors fired after the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms said the changes are not enough. ``As long as the paper does not say goodbye to people whose names have become symbols of an ignorant policy of force, stupidity and total professional failure, and as long as the paper is not credible, it will do more harm than good to progressive forces in the (Communist) party,'' the statement concluded. Pavel, who has overseen drastic changes at that have brought long-banned artists and exiled politicians and others back onto the TV screen after 20 years, said last week he is also fighting demands for even more change, particularly in the news department. Sources at state TV say its reporters are seeking the resignation of at least eight editors deemed to have been too active in pushing the old policies in the past.
